{{about|fashionable clothing identified and marketed as 'sportswear'|clothing for sports|Sportswear (activewear)}} [[File:1920sportsuit.jpg|thumb|Woman wearing a "sport suit," American, June 1920. Sportswear originally described interchangeable separates, as here.]] '''Sportswear''' is an American fashion term originally used to describe separates, but which, since the 1930s, has come to be applied to day and evening fashions of varying degrees of formality that demonstrate a specific relaxed approach to their design, while remaining appropriate for a wide range of social occasions. The term is not necessarily synonymous with [[Sportswear (activewear)|activewear]], clothing designed specifically for participants in sporting pursuits. Although sports clothing was available from European [[haute couture]] houses and "sporty" garments were increasingly worn as everyday or informal wear, the early American sportswear designers were associated with ready-to-wear manufacturers. While most fashions in America in the early 20th century were directly copied from, or influenced heavily by Paris, American sportswear became a home-grown exception to this rule, and could be described as the '''American Look'''. Sportswear was designed to be easy to look after, with accessible fastenings that enabled a modern [[emancipation of women|emancipated woman]] to dress herself without a [[lady's maid|maid]]'s assistance.
==Definition== Sportswear has been called America's main contribution to the [[history of fashion design]],<ref name=fdf>{{cite book| last = Calasibetta| first = Charlotte Mankey| title = Fairchild's Dictionary of Fashion (2nd edition)| publisher = Fairchild Publications, New York| year = 1988| pages =545| ISBN = 1-56367-235-9}}</ref> developed to cater to the needs of the increasingly fast-paced lifestyle of American women.<ref name=nyf>{{cite book |last=Stanfill |first=Sonnet |title=New York Fashion |publisher=V&A Publications, London |year=2007 |pages=28–49| ISBN = 978-1-85177-499-9}}</ref> It started out as a fashion industry term describing informal and interchangeable separates (i.e., blouses, shirts, skirts and shorts),<ref name=nyf/> and in the 1920s became a popular word for relaxed, casual wear typically worn for [[spectator sport]]s.<ref name=fdf/> Since the 1930s the term has been used to describe both day and evening fashions of varying degrees of formality that demonstrate this relaxed approach while remaining appropriate wear for many business or social occasions.<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/sportswear "Sportswear"]. Dictionary.com. ''The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language'', Fourth Edition. Houghton Mifflin Company, 2004. (accessed: March 11, 2009)</ref>
The curator [[Richard Martin (curator)|Richard Martin]] put on an exhibition on sportswear in 1985 at the [[Fashion Institute of Technology]], in which he described sportswear as "an American invention, an American industry, and an American expression of style."<ref name=martin>{{cite book |author1=Richard Martin |authorlink1=Richard Martin (curator)|editor1-last=Martin |editor1-first=Richard |editor1-link=Richard Martin (curator) |title=All-American: A Sportswear Tradition|publisher=Fashion Institute of Technology |pages=8–21 |language=en |chapter=All American: A Sportswear Tradition}}</ref> For Martin, American sportswear was an expression of various predominantly middle-class aspects of American culture, including health ideals, the concept of democracy, ideas of comfort and function, and innovative design which might refer to historical concepts or leisure attributes.<ref name=martin/> The establishment of a five-day working week and an eight-hour working day in America in the mid-20th century led to the need for clothing which enabled the fullest possible enjoyment of such increased leisure time, and was designed accordingly.<ref name=martin/> A subsequent exhibition of 1930s-70s sportswear, also curated by Martin, at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in 1998, was introduced by [[Philippe de Montebello]] as showing pioneering garments, whose modesty, comparative simplicity, and wearability treated fashion as a "pragmatic art."<ref name=montebello>{{cite book|last1=de Montebello|first1=Philippe|authorlink1=Philippe de Montebello|editor1-last=Martin|editor1-first=Richard |editor1-link=Richard Martin (curator)|title=American ingenuity : sportswear, 1930s - 1970s |date=1998 |publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art|location=New York |isbn=9780870998638 |pages=7–8 |url=http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/42547|chapter=Foreword}}</ref> de Montebello carefully explained how significant American designers such as [[Norman Norell]], [[Pauline Trigère]], [[Charles James (designer)|Charles James]] and [[Mainbocher]], were not considered sportswear designers, as they were not dedicated to the design principles of versatility, accessibility and affordability in the way that [[Claire McCardell]] or [[Emily Wilkens]] were.<ref name=montebello/>
The "American Look," which is an alternative term for American sportswear, was coined in 1932 by [[Lord & Taylor]] executive [[Dorothy Shaver]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hDkVCwAAQBAJ|title=Clothing and Fashion: American Fashion from Head to Toe |last=F|first=José Blanco|last2=Hunt-Hurst|first2=Patricia Kay|last3=Lee|first3=Heather Vaughan |last4=Doering |first4=Mary |date=2015-11-23 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |isbn=9781610693103|language=en}}</ref>
==History of sportswear design== [[File:Redfern suit and rugby players 1914.jpg|thumb|upright|200px|Pre-sportswear tailormade by Redfern. ''[[La Gazette du Bon Ton|Bon Ton]]'', April 1914.]]
===Pre-1920=== Sportswear originally described activewear - clothing made specifically for sport. Part of the evolution of sportswear was triggered by 19th-century developments in female activewear, such as early bathing or cycling costumes, which demanded shorter skirts, [[bloomers (clothing)|bloomers]], and other specific garments to enable mobility, whilst sports such as tennis or [[croquet]] could be played in barely-modified conventional dress.<ref name=martin/> One of the first couturiers to specialise in sports-specific clothing was the British [[Redfern (couture)|John Redfern]] who in the 1870s began designing tailored garments for increasingly active women who [[equestrianism|rode]], played [[tennis]], went [[yachting]], and did [[archery]]. Redfern's clothes, although intended for specific sporting pursuits, were adopted as everyday wear by his clients, making him probably the first sportswear designer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Walking costume by Redfern |url=https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O154069/walking-costume-redfern-john/|website=V&A Search the Collections |publisher=V&A Museum |accessdate=24 March 2017|language=en}}</ref> Also in the late nineteenth century, garments associated with activewear and/or modified from menswear, such as the [[shirt]]waist began to form part of the working woman's wardrobe.<ref name=arnoldorigin>{{cite book |last1=Arnold |first1=Rebecca |title=The American look : fashion, sportswear and the image of women in 1930s and 1940s New York |date=2008 |publisher=I. B. Tauris |location=London |isbn=9781860647635 |pages=23–29 |chapter=New York and the Evolution of Sportswear 1929-39: Sportswear}}</ref> Prior to 1920, men and women could both demonstrate their being at leisure simply by removing a jacket, either literally in the case of menswear, or metaphorically by a woman wearing a shirtwaist blouse that resembled a man's shirt worn without a jacket.<ref name=martin/>
Martin has observed that in America, prior to increasing worker freedoms from the mid-late 19th century onwards, leisure had been a luxury available only to the leisured classes during the [[Industrial Revolution]] (c.1760-1860), and before that, [[History of the Puritans in North America|Puritan America]] had condemned leisure for all. He cites the 1884 [[Georges Seurat]] painting ''[[A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte]]'' as an immobile, "static and stratified" depiction of leisure in "direct antithesis" of the relaxed, casual American equivalent.<ref name=martin/> T.J. Clarke notes how ''La Grande Jatte'' illustrates people from the breadth of Paris society taking advantage of their free time by going to the riverside to show off new clothes, but that the act of removing one's jacket or otherwise loosening garments as a signifier of actually being at leisure was almost never done.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Clark|first1=T. J.|title=The Painting of Modern Life: Paris in the Art of Manet and His Followers|date=1985|publisher=Princeton University Press |isbn=9781400866878 |page=267 |language=en}}</ref>
===1920s=== While 1920s Paris designers offered [[haute couture]] designs that could be considered sportswear, it was typically not their design focus.<ref name=rm>Martin, Richard, [http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/amsp/hd_amsp.htm American Ingenuity: Sportswear 1930s-1970s] in Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History. New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2000–. (October 2004)</ref> A notable exception was the tennis player [[Jane Régny]] (the pseudonym of Madame Balouzet Tillard de Tigny), who opened a couture house specialising in clothing for sport and travel.<ref name=arnoldorigin/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Staff writer |title=The Dressmakers of France |url=http://www.gbacg.org/costume-resources/original/articles/dressmakers.pdf |accessdate=19 November 2015 |work=Fortune |publisher=Time, Inc |date=August 1932}}</ref><ref name=stewart>{{cite book |last1=Stewart |first1=Mary Lynn |title=Dressing modern Frenchwomen : marketing haute couture, 1919-1939 |date=2008 |publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press |location=Baltimore |isbn=9780801888038 |pages=209–10 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2Rsc2A0t_BMC&pg=PA209}}</ref> Another famous tennis player, [[Suzanne Lenglen]], was director of the sportswear department at [[Jean Patou]].<ref name=stewart/> In contrast to the flexibility of American sportswear, these expensive couture garments were typically prescribed for very specific circumstances.<ref name=rm/><ref name=stewart/> Many couturiers began designing clothing that, whilst suitable for sport, could be worn in a wider range of contexts.<ref name=stewart/> [[Coco Chanel]], who promoted her own active, financially independent lifestyle through relaxed jersey suits and uncluttered dresses, became famous for clothes of "the sports type."<ref name=arnoldorigin/><ref>Krick, Jessa. [http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/chnl/hd_chnl.htm "Gabrielle "Coco" Chanel (1883–1971) and the House of Chanel"]. In Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History. New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2000–. (October 2004)</ref> In 1926 ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]'' reported upon Chanel's sporty garments, noting the absence of equivalent apparel from New York fashion presentations.<ref name=arnoldorigin/> However, Martin has noted that while Chanel was undeniably important and influential, her work was always based on couture construction rather than the easy-wear nature of American sportswear.<ref name=martin/>
As more generic, versatile sportswear became more prominent in the Paris collections, the press increasingly promoted the wearing of such garments in an everyday context.<ref name=stewart/> By the mid-1920s, American advertisers also began actively pushing the idea that sporty clothing was just as appropriate for regular daywear as it was for active pursuits, presenting it as the epitome of modernity and the American ideal.<ref name=arnoldorigin/> One advertisement put out by [[Abercrombie & Fitch]] in ''Vogue'' in 1929 suggested that while men might admire a girl in an glamorous evening gown, they would be less intimidated by her approachable, friendly appearance in good-quality sportswear.<ref name=arnoldorigin/><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Advertisement |title=Advertisement caption for Abercrombie and Fitch |journal=Vogue |date=16 March 1929 |page=15}} Cited by Arnold, p.24</ref> Sportswear was also presented as an accessible version of [[resort wear]], a term for the luxurious travelling clothing and holiday wear worn by those who could afford a leisurely lifestyle with multiple vacations, such as cruises, yachting, and [[skiing]].<ref name=arnoldorigin/> Affordable, well-designed all-American sportswear was presented as a way of enabling a less wealthy customer to feel part of that same lifestyle.<ref name=arnoldorigin/> However, at first, American apparel firms mostly copied French styles.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wwd.com/globe-news/ready-to-wear-sportswear/sportswear-an-american-invention-6241103/|title=Sportswear: An American Invention|last=Lockwood|first=Lisa|date=2012-09-08|language=en-US |access-date=2016-07-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BUH0AwAAQBAJ|title=Fashion Design, Referenced: A Visual Guide to the History, Language, and Practice of Fashion|last=Kennedy|first=Alicia|last2=Stoehrer|first2=Emily Banis |last3=Calderin |first3=Jay |date=2013-02-01|publisher=Rockport Publishers|isbn=9781610582018|language=en}}</ref>
Despite the acceptance of fashionable sportswear as a form of casual dressing in French fashion in the 1920s, the American garment industry went on to become the most prominent producers of such clothing.<ref name=stewart/> The key difference between French and American sportswear was that French sportswear was usually a small part of a high-end designer's output, while the American sportswear designers focused on affordable, versatile, easy-care garments that could be mass-produced and were relevant to the customer's lifestyle, enabling the modern, increasingly [[emancipation of women|emancipated woman]] to dress herself without a [[lady's maid|maid]]'s assistance.<ref name=rm/> Although the influence of Europe, particularly Parisian high fashion and English tailoring, was always significant, the [[Great Depression]] which started in 1929 acted as a trigger to encourage American fashion to focus on homegrown style and design - particularly sportswear.<ref name=arnoldorigin/> With 13 million Americans left unemployed by the Depression, it was necessary to create jobs and reduce the competition from imported goods in order to improve the American economy.<ref name=":0" /> At the same time, the growth of female athleticism and increased female employment fueled a need for simpler and less expensive clothing.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=J.|first=Robinson, Rebecca|date=2003-01-01|title=American Sportswear: A Study Of The Origins And Women Designers From The 1930’s To The 1960’s |url=https://etd.ohiolink.edu/ap/10?0::NO:10:P10_ACCESSION_NUM:ucin1054926324}}</ref>
[[File:Fashionable woman in 1935.jpg|thumb|left|upright|A smart young woman in a lightweight jacket and printed silk blouse. American, 1935.]] ===1930–1945=== The precursors of true sportswear emerged in New York before the Second World War.<ref name=nyf/> [[Clare Potter]] and [[Claire McCardell]] were among the first American designers in the 1930s to gain name recognition through their innovative clothing designs, which Martin described as demonstrating "problem-solving ingenuity and realistic lifestyle applications".<ref name=rm/> Garments were designed to be easy-to-wear and comfortable, using practical fabrics such as [[denim]], cotton, and [[jersey (fabric)|jersey]].<ref name=vs>{{cite book| last = Steele| first = Valerie| title = Fifty Years of Fashion: New Look To Now | publisher = Yale University Press, New Haven & London| year = 1997| pages =27| ISBN = 0-300-07132-9}}</ref> McCardell in particular has been described as America's greatest sportswear designer.<ref name=vs/> Her simple, practical clothes suited the relaxed American dress code, neither formal nor informal, that became established during the 1930s and 1940s.<ref name=nyf/> McCardell once proclaimed: "I belong to a mass production country where any of us, all of us, deserve the right to good fashion."<ref>{{cite book |last1=Batterberry |first1=Michael |last2=Batterberry |first2=Ariane |title=Fashion, the mirror of history |date=1982 |publisher=Greenwich House |location=New York |isbn=9780517388815 |edition=2nd}}</ref> Martin credits the 1930s and 40s sportswear designers with freeing American fashion from the need to copy Paris couture. Where Paris fashion was traditionally imposed onto the customer regardless of her wishes, American sportswear was democratic, widely available, and encouraged self-expression.<ref name=rm/> The early sportswear designers proved that the creation of original ready-to-wear fashion could be a legitimate design art which responded stylishly to utilitarian requirements.<ref name=rm/>
Many of the first sportswear designers were women, including McCardell, Potter, [[Elizabeth Hawes]], [[Emily Wilkens]], [[Tina Leser]], and [[Vera Maxwell]]. A common argument was that female designers projected their personal values into this new style.<ref name=rm/> One of the few male designers at this time was [[Tom Brigance]], who by the late 1930s was regularly ranked alongside Potter as a leading name in mid-range priced sportswear.<ref name=arnoldbrig>{{cite book |last1=Arnold |first1=Rebecca |title=The American look : fashion, sportswear, and the image of women in 1930s and 1940s New York |date=2008 |publisher=I. B. Tauris |location=London |isbn=9781860647635 |pages=9, 107, 120–122}}</ref> Like Potter, Brigance understood how to design smart and fashionable clothing for mass-production, which made his clothes attractive to manufacturers as well as to customers.<ref name=arnoldbrig/> Two other notable male designers of sportswear at this time were [[Sydney Wragge]] and [[John Weitz]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Martin |first1=Richard |authorlink1=Richard Martin (curator)|title=American ingenuity : sportswear, 1930s - 1970s |date=1998 |publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art|location=New York |isbn=9780870998638 |page=9 |url=http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/42547}}</ref>
In the 1930s and '40s, it was rare for clothing to be justified through its practicality. It was traditionally thought that Paris fashion exemplified beauty, and therefore, sportswear required different criteria for assessment.<ref name=rm/> The designer's personal life was therefore linked to their sportswear designs. Another selling point was sportswear's popularity with consumers, with [[department store]] representatives such as [[Dorothy Shaver]] of [[Lord & Taylor]] using sales figures to back up their claims.<ref name=rm/> Maxwell and Potter were two of the first three sportswear designers, along with Helen Cookman, to be showcased and name-checked in Shaver's window displays and advertisements for Lord & Taylor.<ref name=kirkland/> Between 1932 and 1939, Shaver's "American Look" program at Lord & Taylor promoted over sixty American designers including McCardell, Potter and [[Merry Hull]].<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite web |url=http://amhistory.si.edu/archives/WIB-tour/dorothy_shaver.pdf|title=Dorothy Shaver: The First Lady of Retailing |date=2002 |publisher=Smithsonian Institution|access-date=July 7, 2016}}</ref> Shaver advertised her American designers as if they were French couturiers,<ref name=":0" /> and promoted their lower costs as a positive feature, rather than a sign of inferiority.<ref name=":3" /> One of Shaver's retail experiments was a 'College Shop' section in the store, opened in the early 1930s and run by her assistant Helen Maddock, with the intent of offering casual but flattering clothing to young female college students. The stock, however, ended up selling swiftly to adult women as well as to the students.<ref name=kirkland>{{cite book |author1=Sally Kirkland |authorlink1=Sally Kirkland (editor)|editor1-last=Martin|editor1-first=Richard |editor1-link=Richard Martin (curator) |title=All-American: A Sportswear Tradition|publisher=Fashion Institute of Technology |pages=34–43 |language=en |chapter=Sportswear for Everywhere}}</ref>
Among the key designs produced by this new generation of American designers were [[capsule wardrobe]]s such as McCardell's group of five wool jersey pieces from 1934, comprising two tops, long and short skirts, and a pair of culottes; and Maxwell's "weekend wardrobe" of five tweed and flannel garments. Both were designed to accommodate formal and informal occasions depending on how they were assembled and accessorised.<ref name=kirkland/> McCardell also became well known for designs such as the Monastic and [[Popover dress]]es which were versatile enough to work in multiple contexts from swimsuit cover-ups to party dresses.<ref name=kirkland/><ref>Claire McCardell: [http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/C.I.45.71.2ab "Popover" dress (C.I.45.71.2ab)] |Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History" The Metropolitan Museum of Art. Web. 14 Nov 2009.</ref> Other McCardell signatures included [[ballet slippers]] (made by [[Ben Sommers]] of [[Capezio]]) as everyday footwear and functional pockets in skirts and trousers.<ref name=kirkland/><ref name=feal>{{cite web |last1=Unknown |title=American Look |url=http://www.fashionencyclopedia.com/fashion_costume_culture/Modern-World-1946-1960/American-Look.html |website=Fashion Encyclopaedia |publisher=Advameg Inc. |accessdate=17 November 2015}}</ref> Dressy garments made from casual fabrics, such as McCardell and Joset Walker's evening dresses and dress-and-coat ensembles made out of cotton, became a key sportswear look.<ref name=kirkland/> The American couturier [[Norman Norell]] declared that McCardell could make a smart dress to wear anywhere out of "five dollars worth of common cotton calico."<ref name=kirkland/> Other sportswear designs often incorporated elements of sporty informal or casual wear, as exemplified by Clare Potter's evening sweater worn with a long skirt draped like a [[sidesaddle]] riding habit.<ref name=ny>{{cite news |last1=Schiro |first1=Anne-marie |title=Clare Potter, Who Set Trends In Women's Clothes, Dies at 95 |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=980CEFDF1731F932A25752C0A96F958260|accessdate=20 March 2017 |work=The New York Times|date=11 January 1999}}</ref>
Alongside Dorothy Shaver, [[Eleanor Lambert]] was an important promoter of the American Look and sportswear. As founder of the Council of Fashion Designers of America and creator of New York Fashion Week, Lambert is considered the first fashion publicist.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2110513_2110630_2110690,00.html|title=Eleanor Lambert - All-TIME 100 Fashion Icons - TIME|last=Skarda|first=Erin|date=2012-04-02|newspaper=Time|issn=0040-781X|access-date=2016-07-07}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/gioia-diliberto/eleanor-of-seventh-avenue_b_268619.html|title=Eleanor Of Seventh Avenue: Where Fashion Week Came From|last=Collection|first=Gioia Diliberto Journalist and author of The|date=2009-11-09|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-07-07}}</ref> In the summer of 1940, Lambert was hired by the Dress Institute to promote American fashion, leading to newspaper and magazine articles about how New York was replacing Paris as a global fashion leader.<ref name=":4" /> In 1940, both ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]'' and ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' published issues devoted to American fashion.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oFiTBAAAQBAJ|title=Body and Nation: The Global Realm of U.S. Body Politics in the Twentieth Century|last=Rosenberg|first=Emily S.|last2=Fitzpatrick|first2=Shanon|date=2014-07-30|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=9780822376712|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.harpersbazaar.com/fashion/designers/a15125/bonnie-cashin/|title=How Fashion Legend Bonnie Cashin Broke Into Bazaar|date=2016-04-15|access-date=2016-07-07}}</ref>
Rebecca Arnold and Emily S. Rosenberg have noted how the American look, demonstrated through healthy teeth and the use of affordable, good-quality fashionable clothing to present a neat and practical appearance, despite claims of [[egalitarianism]], was ultimately held up against [[Definitions of whiteness in the United States|white standards]] of beauty.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Arnold |first1=Rebecca |title=The American look : fashion, sportswear, and the image of women in 1930s and 1940s New York |date=2008 |publisher=I. B. Tauris |location=London |isbn=9781860647635 |pages=47–48}}</ref><ref name=rosenberg>{{cite book |last1=Rosenberg |first1=Emily S. |last2=Fitzpatrick |first2=Shanon |title=Body and Nation: The Global Realm of U.S. Body Politics in the Twentieth Century|date=30 Jul 2014 |publisher=Duke University Press |isbn=9780822376712}}</ref> Rosenberg has pointed out a six-page spread in ''LIFE'' dated May 21, 1945, which explicitly described girls with an athletic 'American look' of good teeth, good grooming, and good, not-too-masculine, simple, neat attire, as being seen as preferable to girls from England, France, Australia or Polynesia.<ref name=rosenberg/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lewis|first1=Nina|title=What is the American Look?|journal=LIFE|date=21 May 1945 |pages=87–91 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=50kEAAAAMBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
===1946–1970=== [[File:Claire McCardell on the cover of TIME, May 2 1955.jpg|thumb|right|Claire McCardell surrounded by models wearing her designs, 2 May 1955. ([[Time (magazine)|TIME]])]] After the Second World War, the emergence in Paris of the luxurious "New Look" popularised by [[Christian Dior]], with its emphasis on accessorising and femininity, was in direct contrast to the relaxed, easy-wear [[American Look (fashion movement)|American look]].<ref name=feal/> [[Sally Kirkland (editor)|Sally Kirkland]], a fashion editor at ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' and ''[[Life (magazine)|LIFE]]'', noted that McCardell and others had already been thinking along the lines of longer and fuller skirts and fitted bodices, but that unlike Dior's heavily stiffened and corseted designs, they used [[bias cutting|bias-cut]] bodices and lightweight, easy-wear circle or pleated skirts to reproduce the same silhouette.<ref name=kirkland/> Unlike traditional made-to-measure French couture fashion, designed for specific silhouettes, American sportswear was designed to accommodate a variety of body shapes and enable freedom of movement.<ref name=feal/> With the lifting of fabric rationing and restrictions following the War, American designers were able to use unlimited fabric and the development of permanent pleating meant that pleated dresses and full skirts were easy to look after.<ref name=kirkland/> In addition to this, American stores had begun to recognise the commercial value of separates, with ''LIFE'' reporting in 1949 that separates made up an all-time-high of 30% of clothing sales in the States that Fall.<ref name=kirkland/>
In the 1950s and 1960s, designers continued to develop the theme of affordable, practical and innovative sportswear, producing clothing that focused on wearability rather than fashion fads, including [[Anne Fogarty]]'s coat-and-dress sets and dresses made with removable waistcoats to alter their look.<ref>{{cite book |last1=O'Neill |first1=William L. |title=The Scribner Encyclopedia of American Lives: The 1960s |publisher=Cengage Gale |isbn=9780684806662 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9RSSmwEACAAJ&dq|language=en}}</ref><ref>"Anne Fogarty: Day dress and coat (C.I.63.47.3ab)". In Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History. New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2000–. http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/C.I.63.47.3ab (October 2006) Accessed February 18, 2012</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Fashion Czars Flirting with Lowered Waists |url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/141378859/|work=The Pittsburgh Press |via=[[Newspapers.com]] {{subscription}}|date=14 January 1960|pages=13|language=en}}</ref> The film costume designer [[Bonnie Cashin]], who started producing ready-to-wear clothing in 1949, is considered one of the most influential American sportswear designers.<ref name=kirkland/> She was known for her extremely practical layered ensembles inspired by ethnographic garments and textiles such as the Japanese [[kimono]] and [[happi]], [[ikat]]s, and the South American [[poncho]].<ref name=kirkland/><ref>{{cite book |last1=Steele |first1=Valerie |last2=Mears |first2=Patricia |title=Isabel Toledo: Fashion from the Inside Out|publisher=Yale University Press |isbn=9780300145830 |page=109 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DpfrAAAAMAAJ&q|language=en}}</ref><ref name=lacash>{{cite news|last1=Times Staff |title=Bonnie Cashin; Influential Fashion Designer |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/feb/06/local/me-61631 |accessdate=20 March 2017|work=Los Angeles Times|agency=Wire Reports|date=6 February 2000}}</ref> Her designs incorporated leather bindings, pockets with purse clasps, hooded jersey dresses and tops, and industrial zippers and fastenings.<ref name=kirkland/><ref name=lacash/> She put a brass clip resembling those used on [[leash|dog leashes]], on a long formal skirt so that it could be securely hitched up to enable the wearer to run up and down stairs,<ref name=lacash/> and her ponchoes and hoods (which could be rolled down to form elegant cowl-collars) were originally designed for driving on cool mornings.<ref name=kirkland/> Cashin became one of the first American designers to have an international reputation.<ref name=kirkland/> Alongside Cashin, [[Rudi Gernreich]] emerged in the 1950s as a key name in sportswear design, first becoming known for his swimsuits, but then expanding into geometrically cut, graphic clothes and knitwear that Kirkland described as the epitome of the "new California."<ref name=kirkland/>
Along with many other designers, Gernreich took advantage of the development in the mid-1950s of upgraded machine-knitting techniques to produce his work.<ref name=kirkland/> [[Double knitting]] (which was developed in Italy) enabled the mass-production of easy-to-wear knitted suits, coats and dresses that retained their shape and became a key American look in the 1960s and '70s.<ref name=kirkland/><ref name=vs2/> Another knitwear development involved varying the lines of the classic [[T-shirt]] so that it could be extended into dress-length versions, long or short sleeves, and other variations, including, by 1960, a sequined long evening version by [[Nine West Holdings|Kasper]] for Arnold & Fox.<ref name=kirkland/> In the 1960s, American sportswear depended on very simple shapes, often made in vivid colours and bold, geometric prints (such as those by Gernreich and [[Donald Brooks]]).<ref name=kirkland/>
Towards the end of the 1960s, many sportswear designers such as [[Anne Klein]] and [[Halston]] began to enter business independently, rather than relying on the backing of their manufacturers, or working in association with firms and companies.<ref name=kirkland/>
===1970–2000=== In a 1974 essay titled "Recession Dressing," the writer [[Kennedy Fraser]] noted how Halston's work, particularly his success with making basic garments in luxurious fabrics, was that of an "anti-designer" who liberated American women of fashion from needlessly elaborate, conventional high fashion from high-end establishment American designers. She also singled out [[Clovis Ruffin]] and [[Stephen Burrows (designer)|Stephen Burrows]].<ref name=fraser>{{cite book |last1=Fraser |first1=Kennedy |authorlink1=Kennedy Fraser |title=The fashionable mind: reflections on fashion, 1970-1981 |date=1981 |publisher=Knopf |chapter=Recession dressing (1974)}}</ref> Alongside [[Calvin Klein]], [[Jhane Barnes]], and [[Ralph Lauren]], Martin has described Halston, Ruffin and Burrows as "paragons" of 1970s and early 1980s Seventh Avenue sportswear style.<ref name=martin/>
During the 1970s, Lauren, Calvin Klein and [[Perry Ellis]] became particularly known for their sportswear designs, made in all-natural fibres such as wool, combed cotton, and linen, which placed them at the top tier of American fashion design alongside the Anne Klein label (designed by [[Donna Karan]] and Louis Dell'Olio).<ref name=kirkland/> ''[[Newsweek]]'' in 1975 described Calvin Klein as having styled his clean, casual separates with the authority of a couture designer, and by 1985, Martin described him as "one of the great American stylists" with a solid international reputation and worldwide influence entirely based on his skills as a sportswear designer.<ref name=martin/> The industry empires of Lauren and Calvin Klein would be joined in the mid-1980s by Donna Karan's own-name label and [[Tommy Hilfiger]], each of whom created distinctive wardrobes for the American woman based upon stylish but wearable, comfortable and interchangeable multi-purpose clothes that combined practicability with luxury.<ref name=nyf/> These clothes were also designed to have a long, stylish and undated life, rather than to only be fashionable for one season.<ref name=martin/> In 1976, the designer [[Zoran (designer)|Zoran]] brought out the first of a number of collections of extremely simple garments made of the finest quality fabrics; garments that barely changed over the years and which became cult objects to his wealthy clientele.<ref name=menkes>{{cite news |last1=Menkes |first1=Suzy |title=Simply Modern:Contrasting Looks at Luxury for the 1990s |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/09/28/style/28iht-zoran.html |accessdate=2 March 2015 |work=The New York Times |date=28 September 1993}}</ref> In 1993, the fashion journalist [[Suzy Menkes]] declared Zoran's less-is-more sportswear prophetic of the early 1990s modernist trend, whilst Zoran stated that the work of Calvin Klein, Karan, and the Anne Klein label epitomised the "comfort, simplicity, and practicality" associated with sportswear.<ref name=menkes/> Most early 21st century sportswear design follows in the footsteps of these designers.<ref name=nyf/> Other notable sportswear designers of the late 20th century include [[Norma Kamali]], whose 1980s fashionable garments made from [[sweatshirt]] fabric were highly influential;<ref name=martin/><ref name=kirkland/> [[Marc Jacobs]], whose eponymous label renowned for layered informality in both day and evening wear was founded in 1986, and [[Isaac Mizrahi]], who presented his first collection in 1987.<ref name=nyf/>
In the 1970s [[Geoffrey Beene]], one of the first significant male sportswear designers, incorporated relaxed layering and elements of menswear into his women's clothing - details that continue to widely influence early 21st century industry designers.<ref name=nyf/> In 1970, [[Bill Blass (designer)|Bill Blass]], whose fashion career began in 1946, founded his own company, Bill Blass Limited.<ref name=blass>[http://www.biography.com/people/bill-blass-9215129 Biography of Bill Blass (from the ''Encyclopædia Britannica'')]. Accessed 16 March 2012</ref> Blass's wearable designs were designed to be worn day and night and he was said to have raised American sportswear to the highest possible level.<ref name=nemy>[https://www.nytimes.com/2002/06/13/obituaries/13BLAS.html Bill Blass, Whose Clothes Gave Casual an Elegant Air, Dies at 79]. Published 13 June 2002. Accessed 16 March 2012</ref> Like Beene, he introduced menswear touches to his sportswear, which was described as clean, modern and impeccable in style.<ref name=nemy/> Kirkland commented in 1985 that sportswear designers such as [[Liz Claiborne]] and Joan Vass were no longer "borrowing from the boys," but had begun making menswear too.<ref name=kirkland/> In addition to the high-end names who produced apparel in large quantity, a more personal level of sportswear was offered in the early 1980s by smaller designers such as [[Mary Jane Marcasiano]] and Vass, who specialised in hand-knits in wool and cotton.<ref name=kirkland/> By the mid-1980s, sportswear had become a key part of the international fashion scene, forming a large part of America's contribution to the twice-yearly fashion presentations alongside top-end collections from Paris, Milan and London.<ref name=kirkland/>
===21st century sportswear=== [[File:Michael Kors Spring-Summer 2014 01.jpg|thumb|upright|Relaxed easy-wear sportswear by [[Michael Kors]], Spring-Summer 2014.]] In 2000, the ''Lifestyle Monitor'', an American [[trade magazine]] owned by [[Cotton Incorporated]] published that their surveys showed that an average of 64% of women interviewed preferred casual wear, including sportswear as distinct from [[sportswear (activewear)|active wear]].<ref>[http://lifestylemonitor.cottoninc.com/lsm-weekly/lsm-weekly-articles/?articleID=209&prevArticle=387&nextArticle=389 The Monitor Celebrates Sixty Years of Sportswear], Lifestyle Monitor, 23 March 2000</ref>
Notable New York sportswear designers of the first decade of the 21st century included [[Zac Posen]], [[Proenza Schouler]], [[Mary Ping]], [[Derek Lam]], and [[Behnaz Sarafpour]], who were all featured in the Sportswear section of the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]]'s ''New York Fashion Now'' exhibition in 2007.<ref name=nyf/>
Designers who do not typically work in the sportswear tradition such as [[Monique Lhuillier]] sometimes incorporate elements of sportswear and activewear into their work. Lhuillier, mainly known for formal gowns, introduced sporty necklines and aerodynamic elements into her collection for [[New York Fashion Week]], Fall 2011.<ref name=boston>Critchell, Samantha. [http://articles.boston.com/2011-09-12/lifestyle/30145956_1_previews-derek-lam-donna-karan/3 "Fashion world marks Sept. 11 as shows go on"], ''The Boston Globe'', September 12, 2011. Accessed 16 March 2012</ref>
In 2012 [[Tim Gunn]] noted that the boundaries between activewear and fashion sportswear had become increasingly blurred since the 1980s, with many people choosing to wear [[hoodie]]s, [[tracksuit]]s, [[yoga pants]], and other garments explicitly associated with athletic wear as everyday dress.<ref name=gunn>{{cite book |last1=Gunn |first1=Tim |last2=Calhoun |first2=Ada |title=Tim Gunn's fashion bible : the fascinating history of everything in your closet |date=2012 |publisher=Gallery Books|location=New York |isbn=9781451643862 |pages=205–212 |edition=1st Gallery Books hardcover|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pWG9AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA205 |chapter=Athletic Wear: Attack of the Playclothes}}</ref> <gallery> Image:Public Enemy 4.jpg|[[Hoodie]]s and [[tracksuit]]s became popular items of [[hip-hop fashion]] from the [[1990s in fashion|1990s]] to the [[2010s in fashion|2010s.]] Image:3.1 Phillip Lim Fall-Winter 2010 186.jpg|American sportswear for fall-winter 2010 by [[Phillip Lim]], seen at [[New York Fashion Week]] </gallery> {{clear}}
==Outside the United States==
===Italy=== In the late 1940s and 1950s non-American designers began to pay attention to sportswear, and attempted to produce collections following its principle. French couturiers including [[Christian Dior SA|Dior]] and [[Jacques Fath|Fath]] simplified their designs for ready-to-wear production, but at first only the Italian designers understood the sportswear principle.<ref name=dc>da Cruz, Elyssa. [http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/itfa/hd_itfa.htm "Made in Italy: Italian Fashion from 1950 to Now"]. In Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History. New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2000–. (October 2004)</ref> Italy already had a reputation for fine fabrics and excellent workmanship, and the emergence of high quality Italian ready-to-wear that combined this luxury with the casual quality of American sportswear ensured the worldwide success of Italian fashion by the mid-1970s.<ref name=vs2/> Italian designers, including [[Emilio Pucci]] and [[Simonetta Visconti]], grasped that there was a market for clothing that combined sophistication and comfort.<ref name=dc/> This was a challenge to the American industry. [[John Fairchild (editor)|John Fairchild]], the outspoken publisher of ''[[Women's Wear Daily]]'' opined that [[Krizia]], [[Missoni]], and other Italian designers were "the first to make refined sportswear."<ref name=vs2>{{cite book| last = Steele| first = Valerie| title = Fifty Years of Fashion: New Look To Now | publisher = Yale University Press, New Haven & London| year = 1997| pages =104–105| ISBN = 0-300-07132-9}}</ref>
Before co-founding the business that later became Missoni with his bride Rosita in 1953, [[Ottavio Missoni]], himself an athlete, and his teammate [[Giorgio Oberweger]] had an activewear business in [[Trieste]] making wool [[tracksuit]]s christened Venjulia suits.<ref name=sportsref>{{cite web|title=Ottavio Missoni Bio, Stats and Results|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/mi/ottavio-missoni-1.html|publisher=Sports Reference|accessdate=11 May 2013}}</ref> The success of the Venjulia suits, which took into account the need of athletes for functional, warm garments enabling freedom of movement, led to their being worn by the [[1948 Summer Olympics|1948 Italian Olympics team]] (which included Missoni himself).<ref>{{cite book|title=Missonologia : the world of Missoni |year=1995 |publisher=Electa |location=Milan |isbn=0789200481 |page=19 |url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=cyaOUYiOCKbI0QX7vYHQDA&id=bm1OAAAAYAAJ&dq=Venjulia|edition=1st U.S.|author=Steve Piccolo (translator)|editor=Isa Tutino Vercelloni}}</ref> In the 1960s Missoni became renowned for their uniquely colored, mix-and-match knitwear separates based upon activewear,<ref>{{cite book|last=Black|first=Sandy|title=Fashioning fabrics: contemporary textiles in fashion|year=2006|publisher=Black Dog|location=London|page=176|isbn=1904772412}}</ref> which have remained desirable and fashionable well into the 21st century.<ref name=indobit>{{cite news|last=Watson|first=Linda|title=Ottavio Missoni: Fashion designer who transformed the world of luxury knitwear|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/ottavio-missoni-fashion-designer-who-transformed-the-world-of-luxury-knitwear-8611726.html|accessdate=11 May 2013|newspaper=The Independent|date=10 May 2013}}</ref>
The quality of Italian sportswear was recognized early on by Robert Goldworm, an American sportswear designer who in 1947 joined his New York-based family company [[Goldworm]].<ref name=barbara>{{cite book |last=Perso Heinemann |first=Barbara |title=Fashioning an Artful Life: One Woman's Life History in Clothes |date=2008 |publisher=University of Minnesota |isbn=9780549405054 |pages=107–108 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oSqL94evfOsC&pg=PA107#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> Through his second company base in Milan, Goldworm became the first American knitwear designer to take advantage of Italian quality and bring it to the New York market.<ref name=barbara/> In 1959 Goldworm, in recognition of his active promotion and support of the Italian knitwear industry, was made a Commander of the [[Order of the Star of Italian Solidarity]] by the Italian government.<ref>{{cite book|last=Lambert|first=Eleanor|title=World of fashion : people, places, resources|date=1976|publisher=R.R. Bowker Co.|location=New York|isbn=9780835206273|page=224|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q-jbAAAAMAAJ&q=Goldworm+%22Star+of+Solidarity%22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Ms. Mandell, Mr. Goldworm are Married at Makonikey|url=http://mvgazette.com/news/2008/08/08/ms-mandell-mr-goldworm-are-married-makonikey?k=vg530b761bdebde&r=1|accessdate=24 February 2014|newspaper=Vineyard Gazette|date=7 August 2008|quote=His late father was a fashion designer and executive for Goldworm Knitwear based in New York and Milan, Italy. He was awarded the Star of Solidarity and the title of commander by the Italian government.}}</ref>
In the 21st century, Italian fashion remains a leading source for sportswear design outside the United States. [[Narciso Rodriguez]], who is known for streamlined and pared down clothing, launched in [[Milan]] in 1997, but moved to New York in 2001.<ref name=nyf/> [[Miuccia Prada]] revived the fortunes of her family company [[Prada]] with her top-quality sportswear designs in the 1990s, and continues designing for the firm.<ref name=dc/>
===United Kingdom=== Successful British sportswear designers include [[Stella McCartney]], known for her jumpsuits and easy-to-wear separates. McCartney was asked to design the athletic uniforms for the [[2012 Summer Olympics]], bringing fashionable sportswear design to the world of high-profile activewear.<ref>Chetty, Derick. [https://www.thestar.com/living/fashion/article/1064553--stella-mccartney-brings-a-sexy-vibe-to-sportswear "Stella McCartney brings a sexy vibe to sportswear"], ''The Star'', 4 October 2011. Accessed 16 March 2012</ref>

A '''statistext''' is a [[demography|demographic]] category that is artificially contrived in pursuit of a political or ideological goal, particularly when categories are created that respondents would not otherwise apply to themselves.<ref name='Kobayashi'>{{cite encyclopedia |last=Kobayashi |first=Audrey |author= |authorlink= |editor= |encyclopedia=Challenges of Measuring an Ethnic World: Science, Politics, and Reality |title=Representing Ethnicity: Political Statistexts |url= |accessdate= |edition= |year=1993 |publisher=Statistics Canada and U.S. Bureau of the Census, U.S. Government Printing Office |volume= |location=Washington, DC |id= |doi= |pages=513–525 |isbn= 0-16-042049-0}} This 1993 publication is based on a conference held in 1992.</ref> The term was created by Audrey Kobayashi, a Canadian geographer, in 1992.<ref name='Kobayashi'/>
==Canada==
===Legal definitions=== According to the Employment Equity Act of 1995, the definition of visible minority is: {{quotation| "members of visible minorities" means persons, other than aboriginal peoples, who are non-Caucasian in race or non-white in colour;<ref>Employment Equity Act (1995, c. 44) [http://laws.justice.gc.ca/eng/E-5.401/page-2.html#anchorbo-ga:s_3 Act current to Oct 20th, 2010]</ref> }} This definition can be traced back to the 1984 Report of the [[Rosalie Abella|Abella]] Commission on Equality in Employment,. The Commission described the term visible minority as an "ambiguous categorization", but for practical purposes interpreted it to mean "visibly non-white".<ref>{{cite web|last=Woolley|first=Frances|title=Visible Minorities: Distinctly Canadian|url=http://worthwhile.typepad.com/worthwhile_canadian_initi/2013/05/visible-minorities-distinctly-canadian.html|publisher=Worthwhile Canadian Initiative|accessdate=May 26, 2013}}</ref> The Canadian government uses an [[operational definition]] where they classify as visible minorities the following groups: ''Blacks, Chinese, Filipinos, Japanese, Koreans, Latin Americans, Pacific Islanders, South Asians, and West Asians/Arabs.''<ref>Visible Minority Population and Population Group Reference Guide, 2006 Census [http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2006/ref/rp-guides/visible_minority-minorites_visibles-eng.cfm#Classifications Statcan]</ref> However, a few exceptions are applied to some groups, according to the explanation given by the ''Visible Minority Population and Population Group Reference Guide'' of the 2006 Census, the exception is: {{quotation| "In contrast, in accordance with employment equity definitions, persons who reported 'Latin American' and 'White,' 'Arab' and 'White,' or 'West Asian' and 'White' have been excluded from the visible minority population. Likewise, persons who reported 'Latin American,' 'Arab' or 'West Asian' and who provided a European write-in response such as 'French' have been excluded from the visible minority population as well. These persons are included in the 'Not a visible minority' category. However, persons who reported 'Latin American,' 'Arab' or 'West Asian' and a non-European write-in response are included in the visible minority population."<ref>Visible Minority Population and Population Group Reference Guide, 2006 Census - Catalogue no. 97-562-GWE2006003 [http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2006/ref/rp-guides/visible_minority-minorites_visibles-eng.cfm#Classifications Statcan]</ref> }} The use of the term "non-white" controversially refers to those who are not considered by the Canadian government to be Caucasian, and does open the door to ambiguity. For example, people who are Lebanese, Berber, Latin American or South Asian may consider themselves to be white, yet the federal government forcibly imposes upon Arabs and Latin Americans the status of being visible minorities.<ref>{{Cite journal |author=Mentzer, M. S. |date=January 2002 |title=The Canadian experience with employment equity legislation |journal=International Journal of Value-Based Management |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=35–50 |doi=10.1023/A:1013021402597 |issn=0895-8815 |postscript=. }}</ref>
===Examples of use=== Examples of statistexts used by the Canadian government include the forced categorization of non-Europeans as "[[Visible minority|visible minorities]]", particularly [[Caucasian race|Caucasians]] from [[Western Asia]], [[South Asia]], and [[Latin America]].<ref name='Bauder'>{{cite journal|title=Visible minorities and urban analysis |journal=Canadian Journal of Urban Research |year=2001 |first=Harald |last=Bauder |volume=10 |issue=1 |pages=69–90 |issn=1188-3774 |id= |url=|format=|accessdate= }}</ref> Another example of a statistext is the category "Canadian" as an ethnic choice on Canadian census forms.<ref name='Bauder'/> One demographer has speculated that as an ethnic identity, respondents might choose this to voice patriotism, or to rebel against ethnic classification, or to voice an [[Quebec sovereignty movement|anti-separatist]] opinion, and furthermore, that the term has very different connotations in English versus French. (See footnote 5 in.<ref name='Bauder'/>) An earlier version with a slightly different title is available at [http://mbc.metropolis.net/assets/uploads/files/wp/2001/WP01-09.pdf]. These terms do not match the nomenclature such individuals would ordinarily apply to themselves, although sometimes statistexts gain acceptance among the people to whom the term is applied.
The nomenclature of minority groups has a number of effects. Statistexts can empower some ethnic or linguistic minorities in some instances, while marginalizing and prejudicing them in others. Some may be demoralized by the nomenclature applied to them, as when a Canadian feels the government-imposed "visible minority" label highlights one’s "outsider" or "exotic" background.<ref name='Bauder'/> In other instances, nomenclature applied to a minority group may enable them to present a united front for political mobilization.
As well, these contrived categories lump together distinct groups that would not otherwise perceive each other as members of the same group.
===Statistexts as state-sanctioned racism=== The classification "visible minorities" has attracted controversy. In March 2007, the [[United Nations]] [[Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination]] described the term as racist because it singles out a group.<ref>{{cite web| title=UN calls Canada racist for 'visible minorities' tag | publisher=Canada.com | date=8 March 2007 | url=http://www.canada.com/topics/news/national/story.html?id=f469b36e-c587-40e7-98e5-3aa50a371318&k=23802}}</ref>
Another criticism arises regarding the composition of "visible minorities" as defined by the Canadian government. Critics have noted that the groups comprising "visible minorities" have little in common with each other, as they include some disadvantaged ethnic groups and other groups who are not disadvantaged.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Not all visible minorities face labour market discrimination|journal=Policy Options/Options Politiques| date= 2000|first=Derek|last=Hum|author2=Wayne Simpson | volume=21| issue=10| pages=45–48| issn= 0226-5893 |id= | url=|format=|postscript=. }}</ref> The concept of visible minority has been cited in demography research as an example of a statistext, meaning a census category that has been contrived for a particular public policy purpose.<ref name='Kobayashi'/><ref name='Bauder'/>
Since 2008, census data and media reports have suggested that the "visible minorities" label no longer makes sense in some large Canadian cities due to immigration trends in recent decades. For example, "visible minorities" actually comprise the ''majority'' of the population in [[Toronto]], [[Vancouver]], [[Markham, Ontario|Markham]], [[Richmond, British Columbia|Richmond]], [[Burnaby]], [[Greater Vancouver Electoral Area A, British Columbia|Greater Vancouver A]], and [[Brampton]].<ref>{{cite web| title = Visible minorities the new majority| author=Hamilton, Graeme| work=National Post| date=2008-04-03| url = http://www.nationalpost.com/news/story.html?id=417736|accessdate =2012-05-21}}</ref> However, the term "visible minority" is used for the administration of the Employment Equity Act, and refers to its statistical reality in Canada as a whole and not any particular region.
==United States== In the United States, examples would be [[Hispanic-Latino naming dispute|Hispanic and Latino Americans]], [[Pacific Islander American]] and [[Asian American]]. The word "Indian", allegedly created by [[Christopher Columbus]] for the [[Indigenous people of the Americas]], is another example of a statistext.<ref name='Kobayashi'/> While Columbus's use of this term initially had nothing to do with censuses, this contrivance did enable him to classify people in a way that coincided with the goal of finding a trade route to India.
==See also== * [[Discrimination in Europe]] * [[Employment equity (Canada)]] * [[Ethnonym]] * [[Hispanic-Latino naming dispute]] * [[Orientalism]] * [[Racial policy of Nazi Germany]] * [[Visible minority]]

'''''Ten Years of Marriage''''' (结婚十年) is a 1943 Chinese novel written by [[Su Qing]] 苏青 (1914–1982). <ref>http://www.renditions.org/renditions/authors/suq.html</ref> Owing to her authentic descriptions of sexual psychology, Su Qing was described as a bold female writer and her work received mixed praise.
''Ten Years of Marriage'' is a semi-autobiographical work which tells the story of a Chinese woman's life after marriage. It depicts her feelings as a new bride, the bitterness and happiness of delivery, her extramarital love and her associations with different kinds of men.
The protagonist, Su Huaiqin is a woman born into a fatherless household. She was considered a [[Mandarin Chinese profanity|xiaojie]] (someone of poor standing), before she married Xu Chongxian. Her new husband is from a big feudal family. He is called [[Shaoye]] (young master), by the family servants. The novel begins with an official notice of their marriage in a newspaper.
==Characters== The characters in this work are as follows:
*Su Huaiqin: the wife and the main character. ::Su Huaiqin is a woman born into a fatherless household in a feudal family structure. She was a xiaojie, (a person of low standing), before she married Xu Chongxian.
*Xu Chongxian:the husband of the main character. ::Xu Chongxian lives in a large feudal family, and is called Shaoye, (young master), by the family servants.
*Su Yushu: Huaiqin’s mother ::Su Yushu is a devoted mother who loves her daughter, but unfortunately is forced to arrange a bad marriage that destroys her daughter’s happiness.
*Xu Zhengfu: Chongxian’s father *Xu Taitai: Chongxian’s mother *Xu Xingying: Chongxian’s younger sister :: Xu Xingying is a disagreeable person with an unpleasant appearance. She is depicted as a mean girl and often teases Huaiqin, her sister-in-law. She has a great affection for her brother which could be the motivation for her dislike of her sister-in-law.

The film series consists of the following: a first film of the same name as this series, a second titled ''The Jimmy Timmy Power Hour 2: When Nerds Collide'' and a third, ''The Jimmy Timmy Power Hour 3: The Jerkinators''. The films premiered on Nickelodeon between 2004 and 2006, and were subsequently released to home video. The specials combines [[2D animation]] and [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]]. ==Films== {{Further|The Fairly OddParents|The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron: Boy Genius}} ===''The Jimmy Timmy Power Hour'' (2004)=== Struggling with his science project, Timmy Turner wishes that he could be sent to the best laboratory in any universe. When his fairy godparents, Cosmo and Wanda, fulfill this wish, Timmy is sent to Retroville, the [[fictional universe]] of child prodigy Jimmy Neutron, who's sent to Dimmsdale in Timmy's universe when he activates a magical transporter created by Cosmo and Wanda. As they attempt to return to their respective settings, the characters interact with the various side characters of each other's universe and Timmy becomes romantically involved with Jimmy's classmate, Cindy Vortex. But Timmy's meddling with Goddard, Jimmy's robotic dog, and the seizure of the magical transporter from Jimmy by Mr. Crocker, Timmy's insane teacher, both threaten each character's world in turn.{{Cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Jimmy-Fairly-Parents-Adventures-Neutron/dp/B0001JXQ3I|title='The Jimmy Timmy Power Hour' ('The Fairly Odd Parents' / 'The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron')|publisher=Amazon.com|accessdate=October 31, 2015}} ===''The Jimmy Timmy Power Hour When Nerds Collide'' (2006)=== Timmy and Jimmy enter each other's worlds for a second time, both wanting to ask Cindy out to their school dance celebrating [[Friday the 13th]]. In an attempt to gain Cindy's affections, the two engage in a battle of smarts that sends Jimmy and his friends to Dimmsdale. As Jimmy seeks to prove that Timmy is a fraudulent scientist, Cosmo and Wanda struggle to keep their existence a secret from the people of Retroville. Meanwhile, Professor Calamitous, who is of Jimmy's universe, unleashes a surge of anti-fairies from Fairy World that threatens the rotation of Timmy's Earth. Head fairy Jorgen Von Strangle of Timmy's universe gets angered by Jimmy's and Timmy's friends and their manipulation of fairy magic.{{Cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/The-Jimmy-Timmy-Power-Hour/dp/B000CNESL2/|title='The Jimmy Timmy Power Hour 2: When Nerds Collide' ('The Fairly Odd Parents' / 'The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron')|publisher=Amazon.com|accessdate=October 31, 2015}} ===''The Jimmy Timmy Power Hour 3: The Jerkinators'' (2006)=== In their third and final encounter, Timmy and Jimmy make amends while trying to defeat the enemies from their own universes—including a monster that they concoct together—while accidentally rejecting their respective friends in the process, including Cindy. Initially, they are unable to make the monster evil enough to fight them properly, but when they succeed, he absorbs Cosmo and Wanda's magic and Jimmy's intelligence, and begins destroying both children's universes.{{Cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/jimmy-timmy-power-hour-3-the-jerkinators/509970/|title='Jimmy Timmy Power Hour 3: The Jerkinators!'|work=TV Guide|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=October 31, 2015}} ==Production== Each film in the ''Jimmy Timmy Power Hour'' series combines the 2D traditional animation of the ''Fairly OddParents'' and the [[3D computer graphics|3D computer-generated imagery]] of ''The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron: Boy Genius''. This blending of animation techniques was a technical challenge for the studios responsible for both series, according to Keith Alcorn—director of the ''Jimmy Neutron'' production company [[DNA Productions]].{{Cite journal|last=Ball|first=Ryan|date=May 7, 2004|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/tv/jimmytimmy-power-hour-director-talks-blending-2d-and-3d/|title=Jimmy/Timmy Power Hour revision.text:
:''For the early Christian theologian, see [[Pope Clement I]].'' '''Titus Flavius T. f. T. n. Clemens''' was a nephew of the [[Roman Emperor]] [[Vespasian]]. He was the son of [[Titus Flavius Sabinus (consul AD 69)|Titus Flavius Sabinus]], [[Roman consul|consul]] ''suffectus'' in AD 69, and a brother of [[Titus Flavius Sabinus (consul AD 82)|Titus Flavius Sabinus]], consul in AD 82.Gavin Townend, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/298836 "Some Flavian Connections"], ''[[Journal of Roman Studies]]'', 51 (1961), pp. 55-57 The emperors [[Titus]] and [[Domitian]] were his cousins. As a child, Clemens was besieged along with his family in the capitol, when the soldiers of his uncle, Vespasian, were approaching Rome. His father was captured and slain by the forces of [[Vitellius]], who burnt the capitol, but the rest of the family escaped. Clemens' brother was consul with Domitian, shortly after the latter's accession, but the emperor put his cousin to death on the pretext that the herald proclaiming him consul had called him ''Imperator''. In fact, the emperor was more likely motivated by his love for his cousin's wife, [[Julia Flavia]] (who, as the daughter of his brother Titus, was also his niece).[[Suetonius|Gaius Suetonius Tranquillus]], ''[[The Twelve Caesars|De Vita Caesarum]]'', ''Domitianus'' 10. Clemens also married one of his cousins, [[Flavia Domitilla (saint)|Flavia Domitilla]], daughter of Vespasian's daughter, [[Domitilla the Younger|Domitilla]], who was thus also a niece of Domitian. They had two sons, whom Domitian intended to succeed him in the empire, renaming one of them ''Vespasian'' and the other ''Domitian''. However, in AD 95, when Clemens and the emperor were consuls, Domitian had his cousin put to death.Suetonius, ''Domitianus'' 15. According to [[Cassius Dio]], Clemens was put to death on a charge of atheism, for which, he adds, many others who went over to the Jewish opinions were executed.[[Cassius Dio|Lucius Cassius Dio Cocceianus]], ''Roman History'' lxvii. 14. This may imply that Clemens had converted to Judaism or Christianity, the former being more likely, and accompanied by circumcision.http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/4391-circumcision For the same reason, his wife was banished to [[Ventotene|Pandataria]].[[Philostratus]], ''Life of Apollonius of Tyana'' viii. 15.[[Eusebius of Caesarea]], ''[[Church History (Eusebius)|Historia Ecclesiastica]]'' iii. 14.[[Jerome|Eusebius Sophronius Hieronymus]], ''Epistulae'' 27. To this Clemens in all probability is dedicated the [[Basilica of San Clemente al Laterano]], on the [[Caelian hill]], which is believed to have been built originally in the fifth century, although its site is now occupied by a more recent, though very ancient, structure. In the year 1725 Cardinal [[Annibal Albani]] found under this church an inscription in honour of Flavius Clemens, martyr, which is described in a work called ''T. Flavii Clementis Viri Consularis et Martyris Tumulus illustratis''.Cardinal Annibal Albani, ''T. Flavii Clementis Viri Consularis et Martyris Tumulus illustratis'' (Urbino, 1727) Some connect Clemens with [[Pope Clement I|Clemens Romanus]], perhaps the author of the [[First Epistle of Clement|Epistle to the Corinthians]].''[[Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology]]'', [[William Smith (lexicographer)|William Smith]], Editor. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{SmithDGRBM|title=Clemens, T. Flavius|volume=1|page=788}} ==Bibliography== *Grätz, ''Die Jüdischen Proselyten im Römerreiche'', pp. 28 et seq. *idem, ''Geschichte'' 3d ed., iv. 403 *Lebrecht, in Geiger's Jüd. Zeit. xi. 273 *Berliner, ''Geschichte der Juden in Rom'', p. 39 *Kraus, ''Roma Sotterranea'', p. 41, Freiburg-in-Breisgau, 1873 *Reinach, ''Fontes Rerum Judaicaram'', i. 195 *''[[Prosopographia Imperii Romani]]'', ii. 81.G. S. Kr. {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Lucius Silius Decianus]],
and [[Titus Pomponius Bassus]]|as=Suffect consuls}} {{s-ttl|title=[[List of early imperial Roman consuls|Consul]] of the [[Roman Empire]] |years=95 |regent1=[[Domitian]] XVII,
followed by [[Lucius Neratius Marcellus]]}} {{s-aft|after=[[Aulus Bucius Lappius Maximus]] II,
and [[Publius Ducenius Verus]]|as=Suffect consuls}} {{s-end}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Flavius Clemens, Titus}} [[Category:Flavian dynasty]] [[Category:Flavii]] [[Category:Imperial Roman consuls]] [[Category:Executed ancient Roman people]] [[Category:Cultural assimilation]] [[Category:Converts to Judaism from paganism]] [[Category:Italian saints]] [[Category:1st-century Christian saints]] [[Category:Jewish martyrs]] [[Category:Jewish royalty]] [[Category:1st-century Romans]] [[Category:People executed by the Roman Empire]] [[Category:1st-century executions]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Roman consuls dying in year of consulship]]

{{Infobox television | show_name = Tonya & Nancy: The Inside Story | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | genre = | creator = | based_on = | writer = Phil Penningroth | screenplay = | story = | director = [[Larry Shaw (director)|Larry Shaw]] | starring = [[Alexandra Powers]]
[[Heather Langenkamp]] | narrated = | theme_music_composer = Ramin Kousha | country = United States | language = English | num_episodes = | producer = Robert F. Phillips
Brian Pike
Lynn Raynor | editor = Terry Blythe | cinematography = Alan Caso | runtime = | company = [[NBC Productions]]
Brian Pike Productions | distributor = [[NBC]] | budget = | network = [[NBC]] | first_aired = {{Film date|1994|04|30|TV=y}} | last_aired = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = }} '''''Tonya & Nancy: The Inside Story''''' is a 1994 American [[television film|made-for-television]] [[Biography|biographical]] [[Satire|satirical]]-[[Drama (film and television)|drama film]] written by Phil Penningroth and directed by [[Larry Shaw (director)|Larry Shaw]]. It stars [[Alexandra Powers]] as [[Tonya Harding]] and [[Heather Langenkamp]] as [[Nancy Kerrigan]] and focuses on the [[Tonya Harding#Attack on Nancy Kerrigan and aftermath|January 1994 attack]] on Kerrigan and the extensive media coverage surrounding the infamous incident. It was released on [[NBC]] in April 1994, based on [[public domain]] material.{{cite news |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-08-26/features/9408260191_1_nancy-kerrigan-movie-night-tv-audience|title=Remember Nancy And Tonya?|first=Jessica|last=Seigel |newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=August 26, 1994|accessdate=August 11, 2018}} ==Plot== The film portrays [[Figure Skating|figure skaters]] [[Tonya Harding]] and [[Nancy Kerrigan]], and the extensive media coverage following the infamous [[Tonya Harding#Attack on Nancy Kerrigan and aftermath|1994 attack]] on Kerrigan. It features a [[Postmodernism|postmodern]] breaking of the [[fourth wall]] by having [[Dennis Boutsikaris]] play its screenwriter, addressing the audience over the course of the story. It also features, as labelled by ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', various "witnesses" of [[Greek chorus]] [[actors]], discussing their perspectives of different issues and themes as they emerge in the story. One of the last lines in it is "We imprisoned [Tonya and Nancy] in images we use to sell newspapers, soup, and TV movies. They're victims of those that the media serve". ==Cast== {{Cast listing| * [[Alexandra Powers]] as [[Tonya Harding]] * [[Heather Langenkamp]] as [[Nancy Kerrigan]] * [[James Wilder (actor)|James Wilder]] as Jeff Gillooly * [[Susan Clark]] as LaVona Harding * [[Dan Schneider (TV producer)|Dan Schneider]] as [[Shawn Eckardt]] * [[Dennis Boutsikaris]] as the Screenplay Writer * Bonnie Burroughs as Dody Teachman * [[Steve Eastin]] as Ted Raynor, the FBI Agent * [[Ellen Wheeler]] as Pam Bannister * [[Lilyan Chauvin]] as the Skating Judge * Allan Wasserman as the Sports Agent * [[Ellen Geer]] as the Former Skater * John Di Fusco as the 1960s Activist * Carlyle King as the Network Executive * [[Robert Pine]] as the Network President }} ==Production== When asked about her role as Tonya, Alexandra Powers stated "In a lot of ways, it's the role of the year. Nothing like this ever happened in figure skating. Tonya and Nancy were all over the media, day in and day out. To me, Tonya has the best poker face I've ever seen. With all the controversy going down, she had a smile on her face. She still went to the Olympics. That makes an actor interested. She's either really innocent or deep in denial or she's insane."{{cite news |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1994-04-15/news/9404150479_1_alexandra-powers-tonya-and-nancy-skater-tonya-harding|title=Alexandra Powers Of 'L.A. Law' Laces Up An Attitude For Tonya Role|agency=Philadelphia Inquirer|newspaper=Orlando Sentinel|date=April 15, 1994|accessdate=August 8, 2018}} ==Release== The film premiered on [[NBC]] on April 30, 1994, with a rating of 10.4 and share of 19.{{Cite web|url=http://www.tvtango.com/movie/tonya_and_nancy_the_inside_story|title=Tonya & Nancy: The Inside Story|last=|first=|date=|website=TV Tango|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 7, 2018}} ==Reception== Ray Loynd of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' stated that ''Tonya & Nancy: The Inside Story'' "intelligently captures the chaos of the source material. The story may reek of moral squalor and may already be played out in the print and electronic media, but the moviemakers almost make it look fresh." He enjoyed how the "''[[Rashomon]]''-style multiple viewpoints and array of talking witnesses, presented à la the movie ''[[Reds (film)|Reds]]'', continually propel the narrative", giving it a [[Satire|satirical]] tone. Loynd liked how Alexandra Powers portrayed Harding as stranded between [[figure skating]]'s culture of gentility and her rural heritage. He thought that the film did convey the pressures of competitive sports and the relentless demand to win. Loynd also admired the [[Postmodernism|postmodern]] perspective of a scene with television network executives debating how to tell this very story.{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/1994/tv/reviews/tonya-nancy-the-inside-story-1200436535/|title=Tonya & Nancy: The Inside Story|last=Loynd|first=Ray|date=April 29, 1994|website=Variety|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=February 7, 2018}} Scott Williams of [[The Associated Press]] praised how writer Phil Penningroth [[Frame story|framed the narrative]] cleverly, beginning with a [[close-up]] of [[Dennis Boutsikaris]], as the film's screenwriter, musing "Sometimes, I think this could be a [[Anti-fairy tale|fairy tale]]...one of those strange dark tales, where monsters eat little children." He liked that ''Tonya & Nancy: The Inside Story'' was "interpretive", and thought it was generally well crafted, acted, and sometimes poignant. Williams wrote that Alexandra Powers successfully portrayed Harding's insecurities and vulnerability, and that director [[Larry Shaw (director)|Larry Shaw]] kept the story engaging. He also wrote that, although the film could have been "a hasty 'ripped from the headlines' movie-of-the-week with cartoon characters...overacting stale emotions and restating public record", ''Tonya & Nancy'' emerged as less of an "evidence photo" and more of a character study.{{cite news|url=https://www.apnews.com/32f312e2053ef3efcb7abd01bc4feb0d| title=NBC's 'Tonya and Nancy: The Inside Story' Transcends Its Genre|first=Scott|last=Williams|agency=The Associated Press|date=April 29, 1994|accessdate=August 25, 2018}} [[John J. O'Connor (journalist)|John J. O'Connor]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote that the story held few surprises, yet he too admired Phil Penningroth's method of [[Frame story|structuring the narrative]]. O'Connor liked the [[Dennis Boutsikaris]] character alluding to [[Anti-fairy tale|fairy tale]]s while addressing the audience about Tonya and Nancy: "Once upon a time there were two little girls..." He praised how various perspectives were offered regarding the [[caricature]]s of "Nancy the Good" and "Tonya the Bad". O'Connor also enjoyed the [[metafiction]]al scene of television network executives discussing how to produce ''Tonya & Nancy'': "an ingenious ploy to undercut any suggestion of NBC cupidity". He liked that the film commented about how the [[Olympism|Olympic ideal]] has evolved and thought that [[James Wilder (actor)|James Wilder]] portrayed Jeff Gillooly as a compelling character. O'Connor believed that ''Tonya & Nancy: The Inside Story'' generally avoided the artifice of other [[docudrama]]s that "have a nasty habit of distorting facts." He also believed Harding was portrayed with fitting sympathy, as the film chronicled her undoing. The last line in the film was the screenwriter feeling sorry for her: "Some fairy tales don't have a happy ending".{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/04/29/arts/tv-weekend-how-a-confederate-widow-became-the-oldest.html|title=TV Weekend; 'Tonya & Nancy: The Inside Story', NBC|last=O'Connor|first=John J.|date=April 29, 1994|newspaper=The New York Times|access-date=August 15, 2018}} Tom Jicha of the ''[[Sun-Sentinel]]'' also praised the film's narrative, but did not believe it offered an "inside story" with "significant information". He liked that two versions of Jeff Gillooly approaching the conspiracy meeting are presented, and that "it is up to the viewer to sort out what to believe".
